parts: What is the GZK limit with regard to the speed of protons?

The Greisen-Zatsepin-Kuzmin (GZK) limit is not directly about the speed of protons, but rather about the maximum energy that cosmic ray protons can have when traveling long distances through the universe. It's important to note that the speed of protons in this context is very close to the speed of light, but the limit is more focused on the interaction between these high-energy protons and the cosmic microwave background (CMB) radiation.

The GZK limit is approximately \(5 \times 10^{19}\) electron volts (eV). This is essentially the energy threshold above which cosmic ray protons and other similar high-energy particles from distant sources (more than about 50 million light-years away) interact with the photons of the CMB. These interactions typically result in the production of pions, which causes the protons to lose energy. This phenomenon effectively caps the observable energy of cosmic rays from distant sources when they reach Earth, as they lose energy over long intergalactic distances due to these interactions.

The limit is named after physicists Kenneth Greisen, Vadim Kuzmin, and Georgiy Zatsepin, who independently predicted this effect in 1966. This theoretical prediction helps explain why we observe a sharp cut-off in the spectrum of high-energy cosmic rays, which is known as the GZK cutoff.
So in a laboratory setting, protons can be accelerated past this velocity?

The GZK limit doesn't impose a restriction on the velocity of protons that can be achieved in laboratory settings; rather, it addresses the energy levels of cosmic ray protons over astronomical distances due to specific interactions with the cosmic microwave background. 

In laboratory conditions, such as in particle accelerators, protons can indeed be accelerated to energies exceeding the GZK limit. For example, the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN accelerates protons to about 6.5 teraelectronvolts (TeV) per beam, which is significantly lower than the GZK limit but still incredibly high for human-made accelerators. However, theoretically, if we could build accelerators of sufficient size and power, protons could be accelerated to energies beyond \(5 \times 10^{19}\) eV (the GZK limit) without the constraints imposed by cosmic interactions.

The limitation in laboratories is more about the technological and financial feasibility of building such powerful accelerators rather than a fundamental physical barrier such as the GZK cutoff, which only applies to cosmic rays traveling through space.
